bioghist.p: Pauline (1874-1962) and Josephine Goldmark (1877-1950 ) were both graduates of Bryn Mawr College (1869 and 1898, respectively). Pauline Goldmark was a social worker and Progressive reformer, focusing her attention on the research which underlay the policies and programs of social reformers. Josephine Goldmark volunteered at the National Consumers' League and served as publications secretary (1903) and as chair of its committee on the legal defense of labor laws. Pauline and Josephine, along with Frances Kelly, helped to research and write the so-called Brandeis Brief, which the Goldmarks's brother-in-law, Louis Brandeis, used to support protective laws for women workers.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of correspondence between the Goldmark sisters and their cousins Evelyn and George Openhym. Also included are several letters from Henry Goldmark, a video of Dr. Peter Goldmark receiving the Trustees Award from the National Television Academy in 1974, and a copy of Nancy Woloch's Muller v. Oregon, a book about the legal case for which Josephine Goldmark did extensive research.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
